info.headline: Flash Flood Watch issued January 07 at 2:15AM PST until January 07 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Portland
info.description: .Decreasing rain and lowering snow levels will result in the threat of flooding subsiding over the next 12-24 hours. It will still take time for water to work its way down creek and river systems, though. Please see the latest flood advisories and warnings for the most recent flood information. ...FLASH FLOOD WATCH FOR THE EAGLE CREEK FIRE BURN AREA REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM PST THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Flash flooding and debris flows caused by excessive rainfall and snowmelt are possible over the Eagle Creek Fire Burn Area. * WHERE...The western Columbia River Gorge on the Oregon side of the river. The communities of Dodson and Warrendale are the most at risk of experiencing additional debris flows and landslides early this morning. * WHEN...Until 10 AM PST this morning. * IMPACTS...Residents in the vicinity of the Eagle Creek Burn Area, particularly those in Dodson and Warrendale should be prepared to evacuate. Be sure to stay up to date with information from local authorities. Soils are saturated and at a tipping point. Rainfall this morning may result in additional debris flows. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A combination of snowmelt and heavy rain early this morning may lead to additional debris flows in the Eagle Creek burn area. Eight confirmed debris flows and landslides occurred Thursday morning in the western Columbia River Gorge with a period of heavier rain and snowmelt. Additional debris flows and landslides are possible this morning. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: You should monitor forecasts and be prepared to take action should Flash Flood Warnings be issued. Be prepared to evacuate on short notice. Local emergency services are monitoring the situation and will issue a public statement as conditions warrant. PLAN NOW so you will know what to do in an emergency. Keep informed by listening to local radio and television for statements and possible warnings. Follow the advice of public safety officials. There have been several confirmed debris flows within the Eagle Creek Burn Area over the past 24 hours. Large destructive debris flows and mudflows are likely with any additional heavy rain this morning. Debris flows are likely along streams, in canyons and below mouths of canyons in the warned area. Debris flows could overflow normal channels, crossing roads and impacting structures near or below burned drainages and hillsides. If you are in a low lying area around a stream or creek channel, or you hear rumbling sounds, move to higher ground immediately. Do not drive across a flooded area or into shallow debris even though it may look passable.
